identified-content.classifier: Waterways and Other Bodies of Water

abstract.p: Letter from Linda Church-Ciocci of National Hydropower Assn says James Conaway, in his May 8 Op-ed article, wrongly implies that hydropower and healthy rivers cannot co-exist

block.p: James Conaway (Op-Ed, May 8) understates the importance of hydroelectric power in providing this country with clean and renewable energy and implies that hydropower and healthy rivers cannot co-exist. Far from being ''minuscule,'' hydropower is responsible for 11 percent of the country's electrical generation -- 25 percent in New York -- and is the country's largest single source of renewable electricity.

James Conaway (Op-Ed, May 8) understates the importance of hydroelectric power in providing this country with clean and renewable energy and implies that hydropower and healthy rivers cannot co-exist. Far from being ''minuscule,'' hydropower is responsible for 11 percent of the country's electrical generation -- 25 percent in New York -- and is the country's largest single source of renewable electricity.

Hydropower's value to our energy mix grows even more as we consider its clean-air benefit. Because nothing is burned when producing hydroelectricity, hydropower prevents the emissions of additional greenhouse gases.

No doubt some of this country's 75,000 dams have outlived their usefulness. But when a dam provides a community with clean energy, flood management, drinking water, irrigation and recreation, we must consider its benefits.
LINDA CHURCH-CIOCCI Exec. Dir., Natl. Hydropower Assn. Washington, May 13, 1999
